timetable_clash.title: Timetable Clash
timetable_clash.info:
A timetable clash may occur between courses or class sections within a course.

If the course you are enrolling in to is a compulsory course try enrolling in to a different class section (e.g. a different seminar group).

If the course you are enrolling in to is an optional course try enrolling in to a different class section (e.g. a different seminar group), alternatively enrol in to a new course.

Download a pdf guide: Timetable clash (pdf)
Watch the how-to video: Enrolment - timetable clash

add_swap.title: Add/Swap
add_swap.info:
Considering adding or swapping a course.
Before continuing consider the following

accordion.heading: What course are you considering?
accordion.body:
You need to know what course you are considering and whether it is suitable for you.
If you don't know what course to pick look at the course catalogue to help make a decision.
When you know what course to pick email your adviser of studies to find out if it is a suitable choice.

accordion.heading: Are you adding or swapping?
accordion.body:
If you are adding a course it is usually much simpler so long as it doesn't conflict with another course.
If it doesn't conflict then you can most likely do it on MyCampus. If it does conflict then read "Who will change your courses"

accordion.heading: Are you in the Add/Drop period?
accordion.body:
The add/drop period exists to give students time to try out courses and still be able to change without falling too far behind, therefore changing courses outside the add/drop period could result in a lot of extra work for you - especially if you have missed assessment for the course you wish to change to.
Changing courses is still possible however you should certainly discuss it with your adviser to ensure that you make the best decision for you.

Dates for the Add/Drop period can be found here.

accordion.heading: Who will Change your course? You or the College Office?
accordion.body:
Though you can change courses yourself in almost all situations you should goto the Student Support Officer first.
The Student Support Officer can then tell you if they can solve the problem or if you need to go to the college office.
However going to the Student Support Officer is only necessary when you are going to drop a course (this includes dropping a course to pick another course up and any time where you will drop a course), this is because they can add a course before dropping one which means you will never get stuck without a course.

accordion.heading: Getting advice on your proposed changes, are you confident?
accordion.body: Any time you are considering changing courses it is always recommended you discuss this with your adviser as they really are best placed to answer questions and help you decide what is right for you.

fitness_to_study.title: Fitness to Study
fitness_to_study.info: Sometimes, there are health or other personal issues in a student's life that prevent them from normal study on a course.  Hence they are losing time for proper preparation for subsequent assessments.  The University aims to support students in such situations, and this is formally known as "Fitness to Study" - although issues are not due to health alone.  Fitness to Study is usually first considered locally in the School.
